questions.text: The maximum oxygen flow rate which can be kept with a conventional Hudson oxygen mask is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. 10 L/min

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The maximum oxygen flow rate which can be kept with a conventional oxygen mask (Simple Face Mask, also known as Hudson mask) is 10 L/min. This is a standard setting for delivering oxygen to patients who require moderate levels of oxygen supplementation.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. 5 L/min: While 5 L/min can be used, it is not the maximum flow rate for a Hudson mask.
  • • Option A. 5 L/min:
  • • Option B. 15 L/min : This flow rate is generally used with a non-rebreather mask rather than a conventional Hudson mask.
  • • Option B. 15 L/min
  • • Option D. 20 L/min: This flow rate exceeds the capacity of most conventional oxygen delivery systems like the Hudson mask.
  • • Option D. 20 L/min:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ The maximum flow rate for a conventional Hudson oxygen mask is 10 L/min.

questions.text: Which of the following clotting factor deficiency will not affect clotting in vivo? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Factor XII

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Factor XII deficiency will not affect the clotting in vivo. In vivo, tissue factor is the major initiator of coagulation. It is amplified by feedback loops involving thrombin.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presented with recurrent URTI, poor growth, high-arched palate, and impaired hearing. Tympanogram is given as follows. What would be the most appropriate management?( INICET Nov 2021)

questions.explanation: Ans. B) Corynebacterium minutissimum

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describe the operation and management of Mobile Medical Units (MMUs)? (INICET MAY 2021) MMUs are run by the government MMUs are run by external agencies with medical supplies given by the government. MMUs are run by the government and medical supplies are also given by the government. MMUs are run by external agencies and medical supplies are also given by the external agency.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 1, 2, and 3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Services and Resources of MMUs:
  • ➤ Services and Resources of MMUs:
  • ➤ MMUs offer a variety of services, including primary care for common diseases, reproductive and child health services, diagnostic screenings, and referrals to specialized care. They are equipped with facilities for basic diagnostic tests such as blood glucose monitoring, pregnancy testing, and sputum sample collection, among others. Human resources typically include a medical officer, a nurse, a lab technician, a pharmacist/administrative assistant, and a driver/support staff.
  • ➤ MMUs offer a variety of services, including primary care for common diseases, reproductive and child health services, diagnostic screenings, and referrals to specialized care.
  • ➤ They are equipped with facilities for basic diagnostic tests such as blood glucose monitoring, pregnancy testing, and sputum sample collection, among others.
  • ➤ Human resources typically include a medical officer, a nurse, a lab technician, a pharmacist/administrative assistant, and a driver/support staff.

questions.text: Which skull foramen is formed by 3 bones? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Foramen lacerum

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The foramen lacerum is a triangular-shaped foramen located in the skull base. It is largely filled with cartilage in a living individual and serves as a landmark rather than a conduit for significant neurovascular structures (though some smaller emissary veins and nerves might pass through). Importantly, the internal carotid artery courses superiorly to this foramen but doesn't pass through it. The foramen lacerum is bordered by three bones:
  • • Petrous part of the temporal bone: This bone forms the posterior and medial aspect of the foramen lacerum. Sphenoid bone: The greater wing of the sphenoid bone forms the anterior and lateral aspect of the foramen lacerum. Basilar part of the occipital bone: The basilar part of the occipital bone forms the posterior and medial aspect of the foramen lacerum.
  • • Petrous part of the temporal bone: This bone forms the posterior and medial aspect of the foramen lacerum.
  • • Petrous part of the temporal bone:
  • • Sphenoid bone: The greater wing of the sphenoid bone forms the anterior and lateral aspect of the foramen lacerum.
  • • Sphenoid bone:
  • • greater wing
  • • Basilar part of the occipital bone: The basilar part of the occipital bone forms the posterior and medial aspect of the foramen lacerum.
  • • Basilar part of the occipital bone:
  • • The foramen lacerum is covered by a fibrous membrane, which makes it difficult to see and access.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Foramen magnum: The foramen magnum is the largest foramen of the skull and is located in its base. Through it pass the medulla oblongata (which becomes the spinal cord as it exits the skull), the vertebral arteries, spinal parts of the accessory nerves, and the anterior and posterior spinal arteries. It is formed entirely by the occipital bone.
  • • Option B. Foramen magnum:
  • • Option C. Foramen rotundum: The foramen rotundum is located in the greater wing of the sphenoid bone. Through this foramen, the maxillary branch of the trigeminal nerve (V2) exits the cranial cavity to enter the pterygopalatine fossa. It is formed solely by the sphenoid bone.
  • • Option C. Foramen rotundum:
  • • Option D. Foramen jugulare (jugular foramen): The jugular foramen is a large irregular opening located between the petrous part of the temporal bone and the occipital bone. This foramen transmits the internal jugular vein and several cranial nerves: the glossopharyngeal (IX), vagus (X), and accessory (XI) nerves. It is formed by two bones:
  • • Option D. Foramen jugulare (jugular foramen):
  • • Anterolaterally: the petrous part of the temporal bone. Posteromedially: the occipital bone.
  • • Anterolaterally: the petrous part of the temporal bone.
  • • Posteromedially: the occipital bone.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The foramen lacerum's formation by three bones (the petrous part of the temporal bone, greater wing of the sphenoid bone, and basilar part of the occipital bone) makes it unique among the foramina at the base of the skull. Understanding its anatomical context and relations is crucial for interpreting imaging and planning surgeries involving the cranial base.

questions.text: You're a clinician in a busy urban sexual health clinic, and it's been a hectic day with multiple patients presenting with sexually transmitted infections (STIs). The STI treatment kits are color-coded for efficient management, but the new nurse seems a bit overwhelmed with the options. You decide to guide her. Based on the clinical presentation, which color-coded STI kit would you suggest for the following symptoms? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) A-4, B-1, C-3, D-2

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ The National Aids Control Organization (NACO has provided color-coded kits for the syndromic management of sexually transmitted diseases:

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presents with lesion in tibial diaphysis. Histopathological examination is shown in below given image. On IHC, it was MIC-2 positive and synaptophysin positive cells. Most likely diagnosis will be: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Ewing sarcoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The combination of the patient's age, the diaphyseal location of the bone lesion, the classic small round blue cell morphology on histology, and especially the strong MIC-2 (CD99) positivity with some synaptophysin positivity, makes Ewing sarcoma the definitive and most appropriate diagnosis.
  • ➤ The combination of the patient's age, the diaphyseal location of the bone lesion, the classic small round blue cell morphology on histology, and especially the strong MIC-2 (CD99) positivity with some synaptophysin positivity, makes Ewing sarcoma the definitive and most appropriate diagnosis.

questions.text: All of the following conditions are caused by high-risk strains of Human Papilloma virus except: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Laryngeal papillomatosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Laryngeal papillomatosis is caused by low-risk HPV strains (6 and 11) and not by the high-risk strains associated with cancers such as cervical, anal, and oropharyngeal carcinoma.
  • ➤ Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 563
  • ➤ Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 563

questions.text: Gibbs-Donnan equilibrium is mainly due to? ( INICET Nov 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Intracellular proteins

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ At Gibbs-Donnan equilibrium ,
  • ➤ At Gibbs-Donnan equilibrium
  • ➤ On each side of the membrane, each solution will be electrically neutral The product of diffusible ions on one side of the membrane will be equal to the product of diffusible ions on the other side of the membrane The electrochemical gradients produced by unequal distribution of charged ions produces a transmembrane potential difference which can be calculated using the Nernst equation The presence of impermeant ions on one side of the membrane creates an osmotic diffusion gradient attracting water into that compartment.
  • ➤ On each side of the membrane, each solution will be electrically neutral
  • ➤ The product of diffusible ions on one side of the membrane will be equal to the product of diffusible ions on the other side of the membrane
  • ➤ The electrochemical gradients produced by unequal distribution of charged ions produces a transmembrane potential difference which can be calculated using the Nernst equation
  • ➤ The presence of impermeant ions on one side of the membrane creates an osmotic diffusion gradient attracting water into that compartment.
  • ➤ Intracellular proteins are negatively charged non-permeable ions, then distribution of other permeable ions is affected in a predictable way (Donnan Effect) so that at equilibrium their concentration ratios are equal.

questions.text: In a patient with renal stones, the following crystals suggest what etiology? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Triple phosphate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Coffin-lid shaped crystals in a urine analysis are indicative of triple phosphate stones, commonly associated with urinary tract infections and alkaline urine.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male patient underwent hernia surgery and complained of a loss of sensations over the root of his penis during his postoperative recovery. The patient reported no prior history of genital trauma or surgery. Which of the following nerves would you suspect to be the cause of the patient's loss of sensation? ( INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Ilioinguinal nerve

questions.explanation:
Ans. B)

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The treatment of choice for posterior dislocations of hip is closed reduction/manipulation under general anesthesia in cases with no associated fractures.
  • ➤ The treatment of choice for posterior dislocations of hip is closed reduction/manipulation under general anesthesia in cases with no associated fractures.

questions.text: A statistician is examining the scores of a recent standardized test to assess the variability in student performance. She is particularly interested in understanding the extent of score dispersion from the lowest to the highest mark achieved. Which statistical measure should she use to directly determine this? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Range

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The range directly measures the extent of score dispersion from the lowest to the highest value in a dataset.
  • ➤ The range directly measures the extent of score dispersion from the lowest to the highest value in a dataset.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with history of acute MI complains of acute, severe, and diffuse abdominal pain accompanied by multiple episodes of vomiting. Upon examination, his pulse rate is 110bpm with an irregular rhythm, while his blood pressure is 100/70 mmHg. The abdomen looks soft, not swollen, and there are no bowel sounds. What potential diagnosis could be considered for this patient based on these findings? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Acute mesenteric ischemia (AMI)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The given clinical scenario suggests acute mesenteric ischemia as a possible diagnosis. The most common cause of acute mesenteric ischemia is an embolus. The risk factors for acute mesenteric ischemia/embolus in the given clinical scenario are the presence of an irregularly irregular pulse suggestive of atrial fibrillation and a previous history of ischemic heart disease/myocardial infarction.
  • ➤ The sudden onset of severe abdominal pain in a patient with atrial fibrillation or atherosclerosis is the most important clue to an early diagnosis of acute mesenteric ischemia. The pain is typically in the central abdomen and out of proportion to the physical findings. Associated features may include nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal distension, peritonitis, and passage of bloody stools.
  • ➤ Angiography is the gold standard for the diagnosis of acute mesenteric ischemia, and management involves laparotomy. The goal of operative exploration is to reset the compromised bowel and restore blood supply via embolectomy.

questions.text: The rupture of penile urethra does not cause extravasation of blood into which of the following spaces? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Ischiorectal fossa

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rupture of the penile urethra causes extravasation of blood into the superficial perineal pouch, scrotum, penis, and then up to the lower anterior abdominal wall.
  • ➤ Rupture of the penile urethra
  • ➤ The membranous layer of superficial fascia attaches to the ischiopubic rami and forms the lateral borders of the urogenital triangle. Thus, the urine does not extravasate to the thigh.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct for a patient on high dose of penicillin and gentamicin? iNICET NOV 2020)

options.label: A
options.text: TDM is done with penicillin because of narrow therapeutic index

options.label: B
options.text: TDM is done with gentamicin because of narrow therapeutic index

options.label: C
options.text: TDM is done with both because of dangerous side effects

options.label: D
options.text: Both drugs do not need monitoring

questions.correct_answer: B. TDM is done with gentamicin because of narrow therapeutic index
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. TDM is done with gentamicin because of narrow therapeutic index

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Therapeutic Drug Monitoring (TDM) is crucial for gentamicin due to its narrow therapeutic index and potential for nephrotoxicity and ototoxicity. Penicillin, on the other hand, generally does not require TDM because it does not have a narrow therapeutic index.

questions.text: Which amino acid is not used for synthesis of hormones? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Glycine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tyrosine, phenylalanine, and tryptophan are all aromatic amino acids that serve as building blocks for the synthesis of various hormones.

questions.text: Which structures pass between superior and middle constrictor? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) IX nerve (Glossopharyngeal Nerve)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The IX nerve (Glossopharyngeal nerve) and the stylopharyngeus muscle pass between the superior and middle constrictor muscles of the pharynx.

questions.text: A man with FUO has a job that requires traveling around the world. The bone marrow picture is shown below. Which of the following investigation would be the most appropriate in this case? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) rk 39 antigen test, Leishmaniasis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The presence of macrophages with intracellular Leishmania donovani bodies in the bone marrow is diagnostic for leishmaniasis. The rk 39 antigen test is a rapid and reliable method for confirming visceral leishmaniasis.

questions.text: What does the ECG show? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans.  B) P pulmonale

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ P pulmonale, indicated by tall P waves greater than 2.5 mm in lead II, signifies right atrial enlargement commonly due to pulmonary hypertension or other pulmonary conditions leading to increased right atrial pressure.

questions.text: A female patient presents to the AIIMS emergency department with severe fatigue and prostration. She is a known case of chronic stable angina. While collecting a blood sample, you notice the blood has a brownish hue. What is the underlying diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans.  C) Methemoglobinemia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A brownish hue in the blood, especially in a patient on nitrate therapy, is indicative of methemoglobinemia, a condition where hemoglobin is oxidized, impairing its ability to carry oxygen effectively.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a major diagnostic criterion of neuromyelitis Optica? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Focal epilepsy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Diagnostic Criteria for Neuromyelitis Optica Spectrum Disorder (NMOSD)
  • ➤ Diagnostic Criteria for Neuromyelitis Optica Spectrum Disorder (NMOSD)
  • ➤ Most Common Core Clinical criteria:
  • ➤ Most Common Core Clinical criteria:
  • ➤ Longitudinal extensive transverse myelitis (acute myelitis) Optic neuritis, often bilateral Area postrema syndrome
  • ➤ Longitudinal extensive transverse myelitis (acute myelitis)
  • ➤ Optic neuritis, often bilateral
  • ➤ Area postrema syndrome
  • ➤ Less Common Clinical Criteria:
  • ➤ Less Common Clinical Criteria:
  • ➤ Acute brainstem syndrome Acute diencephalic syndrome, which can manifest as symptomatic narcolepsy Symptomatic cerebral syndrome (symptomatic cerebral lesions)
  • ➤ Acute brainstem syndrome
  • ➤ Acute diencephalic syndrome, which can manifest as symptomatic narcolepsy
  • ➤ Symptomatic cerebral syndrome (symptomatic cerebral lesions)
  • ➤ Some patients with NMOSD may have anti-NMO IgG antibody positivity, also known as anti-aquaporin 4 antibody (AQP4-IgG).

questions.text: Arrange in sequence the structures involved in the direct pathway: (INICET NOV 2022) 1. Striatum 2. Globus pallidus 3. Substantia nigra 4. Thalamus 5. Cortex
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. 5,1,2,3,4

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The correct sequence is as follows:
  • • The correct sequence is as follows:
  • • 5. Cortex - provides the initial input to the basal ganglia.
  • • 5. Cortex -
  • • 1. Striatum - receives input from the cortex and is the first structure in the basal ganglia circuitry.
  • • 1. Striatum
  • • 2. Globus pallidus - receives inhibitory input from the striatum and projects to the thalamus.
  • • 2. Globus pallidus
  • • 3. Substantia nigra - provides dopaminergic input to the striatum.
  • • 3. Substantia nigra -
  • • 4. Thalamus - receives excitatory input from the globus pallidus and projects back to the cortex to complete the loop.
  • • 4. Thalamus -
  • • The putamen is located laterally and the internal capsule is located medially to the pallidum. The striatum and subthalamic nuclei send fibres to it. It is the primary basal ganglia output to the thalamus and superior colliculus. Each cerebral peduncle of the midbrain located deep to the crus cerebri contains the substantia nigra. Dopamine levels in the substantia nigra and striata are reduced in Parkinson's disease.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The correct order of structures in the direct pathway of the basal ganglia starts with the cortex and follows through the striatum, globus pallidus, substantia nigra, and ends at the thalamus. This pathway is fundamental in processing motor signals, which is particularly relevant in understanding disorders like Parkinson’s disease.

questions.text: What is vagitus uterinus? (INICET NOV 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: Cry of baby in the womb

options.label: D
options.text: Infection of both vagina and uterus

questions.correct_answer: A. Cry of baby in the womb
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Cry of baby in the womb

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vagitus uterinus refers to the cry of a baby in the womb, which is a rare phenomenon that can occur if there is a rupture of the amniotic sac with air entry.

questions.text: Which Biochemical method is exploited for monoclonal antibody production by hybridoma technique? ( INICET Nov 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Purine salvage pathway

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The purine salvage pathway is critical in hybridoma technology for monoclonal antibody production, enabling the selection of viable hybridoma cells in HAT medium.

questions.text: A patient presents to the casualty following blunt trauma to the chest. A chest X-ray was done. Among the following radiographs, in which case would you further evaluate the patient before putting a chest tube? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 3,4

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Pneumothorax Hemothorax Consolidation Diaphragmatic hernia
  • • Pneumothorax
  • • Hemothorax
  • • Consolidation
  • • Diaphragmatic hernia
  • • Image 3: Consolidation would be managed symptomatically and chest tube shouldn’t be inserted.
  • • Image 3:
  • • Image 4: Diaphragmatic hernia: A direct blow to the diaphragm can cause it to rupture, allowing abdominal contents to herniate into the chest. In the case of stomach herniation into the chest, a nasogastric tube followed by chest radiography can be helpful. Video-assisted thoracoscopy or laparoscopy is the most accurate investigation.
  • • Image 4:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Radiographs 1-2 show hemothorax and pneumothorax. Intercostal chest drains should be inserted into the fifth intercostal space. The safe landmark is a triangle anterior to the midaxillary line above the nipple, below, and lateral to the pectoralis major muscle.
  • • Radiographs 1-2

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of blunt chest trauma, careful evaluation of chest radiographs is crucial. Consolidations (Image 3) and diaphragmatic hernias (Image 4) require specific management strategies distinct from those of pneumothorax or hemothorax, where immediate chest tube placement is standard.

questions.text: In folate deficiency, the False statement is: (INICET MAY 2024)

options.label: A
options.text: High homocysteine and normal methylmalonic acid

options.label: C
options.text: B12 supplementation is recommended along with Folate

options.label: D
options.text: Purine and pyrimidine synthesis are affected

questions.correct_answer: B. Hemolytic anemia is a feature
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Hemolytic anemia is a feature

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Folate deficiency leads to megaloblastic anemia, not hemolytic anemia. It is associated with high homocysteine levels and normal methylmalonic acid levels, and folate is essential for purine and pyrimidine synthesis, which are necessary for DNA synthesis

questions.text: In which of the following conditions do you see punched-out lesions of the retina? ( INICET May 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The appearance of punched-out lesions in the retina is crucial for diagnosing toxoplasmosis. This understanding can aid in distinguishing toxoplasmosis from other infectious or congenital conditions that affect the retina, guiding appropriate diagnostic and therapeutic interventions.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of Kawasaki disease? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Non-purulent conjunctivitis is a feature of Kawasaki disease, whereas purulent conjunctivitis is not.

questions.text: Which gene defect causes familial hyperlipidemia? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) LDLr

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mutations in the LDL receptor (LDLr) gene cause familial hypercholesterolemia, a condition characterized by high levels of LDL cholesterol in the blood due to impaired clearance by the liver. This condition significantly increases the risk of cardiovascular diseases.

questions.text: A pregnant female visited the obstetrics and gynecology outpatient department (OBG OPD) for her regular prenatal examination. Her past pregnancy involved a stillbirth at 28 weeks. She has a history of engaging in sexual relations with multiple partners and recalls a painless sore on her vulva before her previous pregnancy. What initial investigative step should be taken for this patient? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) VDRL

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For a pregnant woman with a history of stillbirth and a painless genital ulcer, the initial investigation should be the VDRL test to screen for syphilis, as syphilis can significantly impact pregnancy outcomes and requires prompt treatment.

questions.text: A young patient undergoing treatment for multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB) presents with symptoms of weight gain, cold intolerance, and lethargy. Laboratory investigations reveal high levels of thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) and low levels of T3 (triiodothyronine) and T4 (thyroxine). Which of the following drugs is likely responsible for these symptoms? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ethionamide.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ethionamide, a second-line drug used in the treatment of multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB), can cause hypothyroidism, characterized by symptoms such as weight gain, cold intolerance, lethargy, elevated TSH, and low T3 and T4 levels.

questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A patient who is a known case of angle-closure glaucoma has been diagnosed with major depressive disorder. Which of the following drugs have to be avoided in this patient? ( INICET Nov 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Amitriptyline

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with angle-closure glaucoma, medications with anticholinergic properties, such as Amitriptyline, should be avoided due to their potential to increase intraocular pressure and exacerbate the condition.

questions.text: How long should elective surgery be deferred for a patient who had cough and fever, after he has recovered from COVID-19, and has not required any hospitalization?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 6 weeks

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Elective surgery should be deferred for 6 weeks in a patient who had cough and fever due to COVID-19 but did not require hospitalization. This ensures sufficient recovery time to reduce perioperative risks.
  • ➤ Elective surgery should be deferred for 6 weeks in a patient who had cough and fever due to COVID-19 but did not require hospitalization. This ensures sufficient recovery time to reduce perioperative risks.
  • ➤ Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9 th Ed. Pg 2423

questions.text: The given peripheral smear is associated with which of the following leukemias? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Chronic lymphocytic leukemia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A child presented with bilateral proptosis. From the peripheral smear, he was suspected to have chloroma. What is the next investigation of choice? (AIIMS NOV 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Bone marrow examination

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For suspected chloroma in the context of AML, a bone marrow examination is the critical next step to confirm the diagnosis and guide treatment.
  • ➤ chloroma
  • ➤ bone marrow examination

questions.text: The graph below shows oxygen dissociation curves. What does the curve marked as red indicate?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Myoglobin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The oxygen dissociation curve for myoglobin is hyperbolic, indicating its high affinity for oxygen and its role in oxygen storage within muscle tissues. This curve differs from the sigmoidal curve of hemoglobin, which exhibits cooperative binding.

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement regarding the marked structure: (INICET MAY 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: It is the meeting point of frontal, parietal, temporal and sphenoid bones.

options.label: B
options.text: Blow to the lateral side of the skull injures the marked structure.

options.label: C
options.text: Accessory middle meningeal artery lies under this structure.

options.label: D
options.text: It corresponds to site of anterolateral fontanelle of fetal skull.

questions.correct_answer: C. Accessory middle meningeal artery lies under this structure.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Accessory middle meningeal artery lies under this structure.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The structure marked in the image is the pterion. The main branch of Middle meningeal artery lies under this structure NOT accessory middle meningeal artery. The accessory middle meningeal artery usually arises from the maxillary artery and enters the middle cranial fossa through the foramen ovale or a separate foramen. Its location and presence can vary.
  • • Other Options :
  • • Other Options
  • • Option A. It is the meeting point of frontal, parietal, temporal, and sphenoid bones. Correct : The pterion is indeed the meeting point of these four bones.
  • • Option A.
  • • It is the meeting point of frontal, parietal, temporal, and sphenoid bones.
  • • Correct
  • • Option B. Blow to the lateral side of the skull injures the marked structure. Correct : A blow to the pterion can be very dangerous because the middle meningeal artery runs just deep to this area, on the inner side of the skull. If this artery is ruptured due to a fracture at the pterion, it can lead to an epidural hematoma, which is a type of traumatic brain injury.
  • • Option B.
  • • Blow to the lateral side of the skull injures the marked structure. Correct
  • • Option D. It corresponds to the site of the anterolateral fontanelle of the fetal skull. Correct : The pterion corresponds to the region of the anterolateral (or sphenoid) fontanelle in the fetal skull. This fontanelle usually closes a few months after birth.
  • • Option D.
  • • It corresponds to the site of the anterolateral fontanelle of the fetal skull. Correct

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pterion is the junction point of four bones in the skull: the frontal, parietal, temporal, and sphenoid bones. The term "pterion" comes from the Greek word "pteron," meaning "wing," because the pterion is located at the point where the sphenoid bone and the temporal bone form a wing-like shape. The pterion is located just above the zygomatic arch and anterior to the ear. The middle meningeal artery, a branch of the maxillary artery, runs underneath the pterion and is at risk of injury in cases of head trauma.

questions.text: The below-given image is characteristically seen in which of the following type of leprosy? ( INICET Nov 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Borderline leprosy (BB Leprosy)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Patients with borderline leprosy are at risk for developing reactions like Type 1 (reversal) reactions, which can lead to rapid worsening of lesions and require immediate medical attention. Accurate diagnosis based on clinical presentation, bacterial index, and histopathology is crucial as the treatment duration and regimen may differ based on the type of leprosy. Borderline leprosy is typically treated with multi-drug therapy (MDT), similar to other forms of leprosy.
  • ➤ Patients with borderline leprosy are at risk for developing reactions like Type 1 (reversal) reactions, which can lead to rapid worsening of lesions and require immediate medical attention.
  • ➤ Accurate diagnosis based on clinical presentation, bacterial index, and histopathology is crucial as the treatment duration and regimen may differ based on the type of leprosy. Borderline leprosy is typically treated with multi-drug therapy (MDT), similar to other forms of leprosy.
  • ➤ Ref - Rooks textbook of Dermatology 9 th edition page no 28.3, 28.5, 28.10
  • ➤ Ref - Rooks textbook of Dermatology 9 th edition page no 28.3, 28.5, 28.10

questions.text: After parotidectomy, lower lip paralysis was seen in a patient. Which of the following part of facial nerve was involved ? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.correct_answer: C. Cervical branch of facial nerve
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Cervical branch of facial nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Damage to the cervical branch of the facial nerve during a parotidectomy can result in lower lip paralysis.

questions.text: In the case of an elderly male presenting with meningitis, a gram stain of the CSF sample shows the presence of gram-positive bacilli. Which of the following statements accurately pertains to the motility of the responsible microorganism? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.correct_answer: C. Motile at 25° C, non-motile at 37°C
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Motile at 25° C, non-motile at 37°C

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Listeria monocytogenes exhibits motility at 25°C but is non-motile at 37°C.

questions.text: Which of the following groups is not considered a core risk factor group for HIV transmission? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Long-distance truck drivers

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The distinction between core risk groups and bridge populations in HIV transmission:
  • ➤ Core risk groups include:
  • ➤ Core risk groups include:
  • ➤ Female sex workers Men who have sex with men (MSM) Transgender populations Injectable drug users
  • ➤ Female sex workers
  • ➤ Men who have sex with men (MSM)
  • ➤ Transgender populations
  • ➤ Injectable drug users
  • ➤ Bridge populations , like truck drivers and migrants, serve as intermediaries in disease transmission.
  • ➤ Bridge populations

questions.text: Which of the following is not helpful for differentiating between necrosis and apoptosis? (INICET MAY 2024)

options.label: D
options.text: Internal organelle disintegration with lipid change

questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The key features to differentiate necrosis from apoptosis include the state of cell organelles (intact in apoptosis, disintegrated in necrosis), enzyme-mediated degradation (present in necrosis), and internal organelle disintegration with lipid changes (present in necrosis). Altered cell shape alone is not a useful parameter for differentiation.

questions.text: Which of the following findings are typically associated with glomerular hematuria? (INICET NOV 2024) Brown urine Dysuria absent Crystals in urine Edema is rare
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) A, B

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Glomerular hematuria includes brown/cola-colored urine and absence of dysuria, while presence of edema and absence of urinary crystals are other important characteristics.
